poem:
### The Sound of Sweet

A vinyl spin on Cathcart Road,  
youth clings to the pulse of pop—  
melodies flickering like restless feet,  
the needle whispers Blockbuster dreams.  
Echoes ride the Glasgow air,  
yet, silence grips the rebel heart.  
Songs cut to bleed, still,  
there's a sweetness in unheard tunes.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘God Save the King makes me sick’: Bobby Gillespie’s honest playlist The first single I boughtBlockbuster by the Sweet in 1973 from Soundtrack Records on Cathcart Road in Glasgow age 11 or 12, after seeing them on Top of the Pops. I loved all the Sweet singles after that. The song I do at karaokeI don’t think I’ve ever done karaoke. I hate hearing people murder songs. If I had to do it, I’d do". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
